Graphical abstract The introduction of WO3 enhanced the capacity of ammonia adsorption of RuO2-Fe2O3 catalyst, as well as increased high-temperature N2 selectivity. The NH3-SCO reaction over RuO2-WO3-Fe2O3 catalyst mainly followed the “internal” selective catalytic reduction (iSCR) mechanism. The key intermediate (-NH2) could rapidly react with the in situ-generated NO ad-species to form N2 and H2O. The promoting effects of WO3 on RuO2-Fe2O3 catalyst were systematically investigated for the selective catalytic oxidation of ammonia to nitrogen. It was found that the introduction of 5 wt.% WO3 led to a dramatic promoting effect on the high-temperature N2 selectivity of RuO2-Fe2O3 catalyst, giving 100% NH3 conversion at 250 °C and 94% N2 selectivity at a high temperature of 400 °C. In depth analysis using XRD, Raman and H2-TPR revealed that the addition of WO3 into the RuO2-Fe2O3 catalyst could strongly inhibit the crystallinity of Fe2O3 and decrease the reducibility of RuO2-Fe2O3 catalyst, which were related to the strong interaction between WO3 and Fe2O3. Moreover, in situ DRIFTS studies illustrated that the ammonia oxidation over 1RuO2-5WO3-Fe2O3 catalyst followed the iSCR mechanism, involving the oxidation of NH3 into NO species and the reaction of -NH2 with in situ-formed NO to form N2. The introduction of WO3 not only promoted the formation of more acid sites on the catalyst surface but also restrained the formation of nitrate species at high temperature, with few NO x formed, which contributed to the high N2 selectivity. Keywords Promoting effects N2 selectivity Strong interaction Acid sites 1 Introduction Nitrogen oxides (NO x ), as one of the major components of diesel exhausts, have caused many inevitable environmental issues, and more stringent standards were applied to regulate vehicle exhaust emissions [1,2]. Currently, the selective catalytic reduction (SCR) of NO x with ammonia (NH3) has been regarded as one of the most advanced process for eliminating NO x [3,4]. To enhance the efficiency of NO x elimination, however, an excess quantity of NH3 is applied, which contributes to another serious environmental problem of ammonia slip. In this context, a great demand to search for a highly efficient and environmentally benign method to abate NH3 is presented. Selective catalytic oxidation of ammonia to nitrogen and water vapor (NH3-SCO) is the preferred choice [5–7]. The total reaction process is shown as follows: (1) 4 N H 3 + 3 O 2 → 2 N 2 + 6 H 2 O More importantly, the NH3-SCO as the after-treatment technology of NH3-SCR from diesel engine requires a highly efficient catalyst operating over a wide temperature range (150–400 °C) [8]. Hence, the development of the novel SCO catalysts with superior low-temperature catalytic activity and excellent high-temperature N2 selectivity for real application in diesel emission control is highly desirable. Different types of catalytic materials have been manufactured and used for the selective catalytic oxidation of ammonia to nitrogen and water [9]. Recently, metal oxides-modified zeolites, such as Cu-ZSM-5, Fe-ZSM-5 and Fe-Beta, obtained by different methods have been explored in terms of NH3 oxidation [10–12] with excellent N2 selectivity, but they require relatively harsh condition of high reaction temperature. In addition, transition metal mixed oxides (CuCrO2, CuO-TiO2, MnOx-TiO2) [13–15] and supported precious metals, especially supported Ag and Ru nanoparticle catalysts [16–18], are studied frequently for NH3-SCO reaction in recently years due to their excellent low-temperature catalytic activities. Nevertheless, most of them suffer from low N2 selectivity at high temperature, which is related to the formation of N2O (reaction (2)), NO (reaction (3)) and NO2 (reaction (4)) as by-products of ammonia oxidation, resulting in more detrimental effects on environments and human health: (2) 2 N H 3 + 2 O 2 → N 2 O + 3 H 2 O (3) 4 N H 3 + 5 O 2 → 4 N O + 6 H 2 O (4) 4 N H 3 + 7 O 2 → N O 2 + 6 H 2 O Therefore, reducing the occurrence frequency of by-reaction by developing one kind of environmental-friendly catalyst is necessary. It is worth mentioning that the clarification of reaction mechanism of NH3-SCO is significative to develop an efficient process properly for ammonia oxidation to nitrogen over catalysts. Previous researchers have proposed some typical reaction pathways through more effective means of research [19,20]. Jones et al. [19] proposed a direct route of SCO reaction involving a hydrazine intermediate, which happened on CuO/Al2O3. Furthermore, He et al. [20] investigated the mechanism of NH3-SCO over Ag/Al2O3 and found that the NH3 oxidation mainly followed the -NH mechanism at low temperature (<140 °C) and the “internal” selective catalytic reduction (iSCR) mechanism at temperature above 140 °C. Unfortunately, it is hard to certain the mechanism of ammonia oxidation due to the nondeterminacy of reaction process on catalysts. Ferric oxide (Fe2O3) has been investigated in NH3-SCO reaction because of its high-temperature stability and high catalytic activity [21–23]. Previous researches demonstrate that Ru supported catalysts are active for ammonia oxidation [18,24]. Shi et al. investigated the RuO2-CuO/Al-ZrO2 and CuO/RuO2 catalysts with 5%–30% and 70-95% Ru loadings for ammonia oxidation, respectively, and found that the catalysts possessed excellent activity and N2 selectivity at low temperature [18,24]. Moreover, some researchers have pointed that the capacity of ammonia adsorption is significantly enhanced by increasing the surface acid sites of catalysts, which contributes to the superior catalytic performance in NH3-SCR [1,25,26]. While the promoting effect of surface acidity on high-temperature N2 selectivity is rarely discussed in NH3-SCO. Considering the function of surface acidity, so, in this paper, we studied a series of WO3-modified RuO2-Fe2O3 catalysts with low cost of 1% ruthenium for NH3-SCO. It was discovered that the introduction of WO3 gave a promotional effect on both surface acidity and N2 selectivity of RuO2-Fe2O3 catalyst for the NH3-SCO in a wide range of reaction window (150–400 °C). Besides, DRIFTS studies were performed to get insight into the origin of the promoting effect of WO3 and reaction mechanism of ammonia oxidation. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalysts preparation For the preparation of Fe2O3, RuO2-Fe2O3, WO3-Fe2O3 and RuO2-WO3-Fe2O3 catalysts, citric sol-gel technique was employed, where analytical grade Fe(NO3)3·9H2O, RuCl3·3H2O, ammonium metatungstate, and citric acid (CA) were employed as raw materials. For the sol-gel route of RuO2-WO3-Fe2O3, a certain amount of Fe(NO3)3·9H2O, RuCl3·3H2O and (NH4)6H2W12O40·6H2O was dissolved in 60 mL ion-free water at room temperature under continuous stirring. The pH value of the homogeneous solution was 1.0. Afterwards, CA in 2:1 M ratio with respect to the sum of metal ion was added in above solution as a chelator and the pH value of the final solution was maintained at 0.7. The mixed solution was stirred at 80 °C until the viscous wet sol was formed, and then the formed wet sol was aged at 80 °C for 72 h to form a brown gel. Next, the obtained dried brown gel was calcined in nitrogen atmosphere at 550 °C for 3 h, subsequently calcined at 500 °C for 4 h in air to burn out the carbon species. Hereinafter these as-prepared samples were noted as 1R-xW-F (R, W and F represented the RuO2, WO3 and Fe2O3, respectively; where RuO2 was in the weight percentage (wt.%) of 1, x denoted the weight percentage of WO3, x = 1, 3, 5, 7, 9). For comparison, the RuO2-Fe2O3 with 1 wt.% RuO2, WO3-Fe2O3 with 5 wt.% WO3 (noted as 1R-F, 5 W-F) and pure Fe2O3 samples were prepared by the same method as above. 2.2 Catalysts characterization N2 adsorption/desorption isotherms of samples were obtained via N2 adsorption at about −196 °C on a TriStar II 3020 apparatus. Before measurement, the samples were degassed in vacuum at 300 °C for 4 h. BET surface areas of the samples were measured using the Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) method. The pore size distributions were determined using the BJH (Barett–Joyner–Halenda) method from the desorption branch of the isotherms. X-ray diffraction (XRD) measurements were collected on a Bruker D8 Advance diffractometer employing Cu Kα radiation (λ = 0.15406 nm), in which the working voltage and current were 40 kV and 40 mA, respectively. Scans were performed from 20° to 80° with a scan step of 6°/min. Laser Raman tests were conducted on a Renishaw inVia Laser micro confocal Raman spectrometer system equipped with a CCD as the detector and a visible Ar ion laser (λ = 514.5 nm) as the ray source. Prior to the test, steady-flow argon was introduced into the sample held at 25 °C for 30 min. X-ray photoelectron spectra (XPS) were examined on an ULVAC PHI 5000 Versa Probe-α using Al Kα X-ray source. The working pressure was required to be 10−9 Pa. The carbon deposit C1 s binding energy value at 284.8 eV was used to calibrate the binding energies. The spectra were calibrated to the C 1 s peak at 284.6 eV. H2-temperature programmed reduction (H2-TPR) experiments were carried out in an adsorption apparatus consisting of a quartz reactor equipped with a thermal conductivity detector (TCD) measuring the H2 consumption. The samples (30 mg) were pretreated with N2 at 300 °C for 40 min to remove the surface contaminants. The flow rate of N2 flow was 30 mL/min. After cooling to the room temperature in N2 and turning off the N2 flow, a flow of 5% H2/Ar as the reduction agent with a flow rate of 40 mL/min was passed through the samples. The temperature was raised from 100 °C to 850 °C at a heating rate of 8 °C/min while the TCD signals were recorded. The consumption of H2 was quantitatively measured by the integrated area of the TPR profiles. The calibration sample for quantitative analysis of consumed hydrogen was pure CuO sample. In situ DRIFTS experiments were measured on a Fourier transform infrared spectrometer (FTIR, Nicolet 6700). The sample in the DRIFT IR cell was pretreated in a flow of nitrogen at 400 °C for 20 min to remove all the undesired adsorbed species, subsequently the background spectrum was collected in flowing nitrogen atmosphere. The background spectrum was subtracted from each sample spectrum acquired at the same temperature. Then, a gas mixture comprising of 600 ppm NH3 in N2 (100 mL/min) or 600 ppm NH3+5% O2 in N2 (100 mL/min) was passed through the samples. And all spectra were collected after reaching the desired conditions. 2.3 Catalytic activity tests The catalytic activity measurements of samples were performed in a fixed-bed quartz tube (i.d.6 mm) reactor conducting in a steady flow mode. 0.4 mL catalysts were used in each test and the operating temperature varied from 150 to 400 °C. The typical compositions of the reactant gas consisted of 800 ppm NH3, 5% O2 and Ar in balance. The total flow rate was 400 mL/min and thus a GHSV of 60,000 h−1 was obtained. The analysis of NH3 concentration was collected on a NH3 analyzer (GXH-1050E, Beijing). The concentration of N2O was monitored by a gas chromatograph (GC-9790) with an electron capture detector (ECD). The NO and NO2 were detected by the flue gas analyzer (ECOM·J2KN). The NH3 conversion was calculated based on the concentrations of the inlet and outlet gas at steady state as the following Eq. (5): (5) N H 3 conversion ( % ) = N H 3 in − N H 3 out N H 3 in × 100 The N2 selectivity, NO x (NO, NO2) yield and N2O yield in SCO reaction were calculated using the Eqs. (6)–(8): (6) N 2 s e l e c t i v i t y ( % ) = N H 3 i n − N H 3 o u t − N O o u t − N O 2 o u t − 2 N 2 O o u t N H 3 i n − N H 3 o u t × 100 (7) N O x y i e l d ( % ) = ( [ N O ] o u t + [ N O 2 ] o u t [ N H 3 ] i n ) × 100 (8) N 2 O y i e l d ( % ) = ( 2 [ N 2 O ] o u t [ N H 3 ] i n ) × 100 3 Results and discussions 3.1 NH3-SCO catalytic performance of as-prepared catalysts The catalytic performances of pure Fe2O3 1R-F, 5 W-F and 1R-xW-F catalysts with different WO3 loading for NH3-SCO were illustrated in Fig. 1 . Significant differences were observed among them. The single metal oxide Fe2O3 showed a mild NH3-SCO activity with 100% NH3 conversion at temperature of about 300 °C. It was noticeable that the NH3 conversion and N2 selectivity of 1R-F catalyst were enhanced above 150 °C. Obviously, as seen from Fig. 1(a) and 1(b), the 1R-F catalysts showed significantly increased activities for NH3 conversion than that of pure Fe2O3 with 100% NH3 conversion and 90% N2 selectivity at 250 °C. However, the N2 selectivity of this catalyst decreased significantly with increasing temperature, especially for high temperature above 350 °C, which might be mainly due to the formation of more NO x (NO, NO2) as the temperature increased (Fig. 1(c)). To enhance the N2 selectivity of 1R-F catalyst, a moderate amount of WO3 was introduced. Generally, introduction of 1% WO3 led to an enhancement of NH3 conversion from 80.7% to 100% at 225 °C, but a sharp decrease for N2 selectively was obtained. In turn, the addition of 3 or 5% WO3 resulted in somewhat outstanding catalytic activity and strongly enhancement of N2 selectivity at higher temperature. With further increasing the WO3 loading from 5% to 7 or 9%, on the contrary, the activity decreased slightly, while the N2 selectivity still increased. In contrast, the loading of WO3 on pristine Fe2O3 led to a pronounced decrease in NH3 oxidation activity, but exhibited an enhanced trend of N2 selectivity. These facts indicated that the addition of WO3 not only enhanced catalytic activity of 1R-F catalyst but also pronouncedly increased N2 selectivity, and the optimum loading of WO3 was 5%. The significant difference between 1R-F and WO3-modified 1R-F catalysts was that the WO3-modified 1R-F catalyst possessed excellent high-temperature N2 selectivity with NO x less than 6% (Fig. 1(c)). Interestingly, the WO3 showed the unobvious effect on N2O yield (Fig. 1(d)). Therefore, the primary objective of this paper was to explore the promotion effect of 5% WO3 on catalytic properties. 3.2 Characterization of catalysts 3.2.1 XRD patterns and BET surface area The structural features of Fe2O3, 1R-F, 5 W-F and 1R-5W-F samples had been investigated by X-ray diffraction (XRD). As shown in Fig. 2 , for the simplex Fe2O3, there were several distinguishable diffraction peaks at 24.3°, 33.3°, 35.7°, 41.0°, 49.6°, 54.2°, 62.6° and 64.10°, which were corresponded to the scattering from (012), (104), (110), (113), (024), (116), (214), and (300) planes of the hematite α-Fe2O3 with a well crystalline pattern (JCPDS 33–0644) [27]. XRD patterns of the 1R-F nanocomposites showed only characteristic peaks of α-Fe2O3. Neither metallic Ru nor Ru oxide was detected at low Ru loading, which was possibly due to two reasons. The one was that high dispersion of ruthenium oxide on Fe2O3 supports in low amount of RuO2 loadings led to no characteristic diffraction peaks of RuO x species that could be observed in the XRD spectra. Another one was that the RuO x species exhibited less ordered structural features or amorphous-like. Apart from that, the WO3 phase in the 1R-5W-F catalyst cannot be directly detected through XRD analysis, which might be due to the incorporation of some tungsten atoms into the Fe2O3 lattice to form W-O-Fe solid solutions; alternatively, the WO3 species were probably highly dispersed in the catalysts [1]. In addition, the intensity of diffraction peaks of Fe2O3 decreased significantly after doping the WO3, implying the decrease of crystallinity of the WO3-modified samples. These results demonstrated that the existence of tungsten on the surface of Fe2O3 could strongly inhibit the crystallinity of Fe2O3, indicating that an interaction between WO3 and Fe2O3 might be present in the 1R-5W-F catalyst. Moreover, the average crystallite size of the presence Fe2O3 phase (DF) was evaluated using the Scherer equation for major XRD peaks of catalysts from Fig. 2. (9) D F = K λ β c o s θ Where λ is the radiation wavelength (CuKα, 0.15406 nm), K is the so-called Scherrer constant (0.9), β is the full width at half maximum (FWHM), and θ is the scattering angle [28]. The calculated results shown in Table 1 revealed that the Fe2O3 mean crystallite size declined with the introduction of WO3. The following order of the mean particle size of Fe2O3 phase was recorded: Fe2O3 (38 nm) >1R-F (37 nm) >1R-5W-F (24 nm) >5 W-F (19 nm). The following order, however, in terms of NH3 conversion at 250 °C, was obtained: 1R-F (100%) ≈ 1R-5W-F (100%) > Fe2O3 (19%) >5 W-F (14%). The present finding demonstrated that the catalytic activity of these catalysts was not necessarily related to the particle size. To explore the textural properties of prepared samples, the BET analysis was performed. Fig. 3 depicted the N2 adsorption/desorption isotherms and the corresponding pore size distribution curves of the prepared Fe2O3, 5 W-F, 1R-F, and 1R-5W-F catalysts. The structural properties were calculated and listed in Table 1. Fig. 3(a) suggested that the isotherms of all the catalysts were of classical type IV isotherm and the isotherm at relative pressure P/P0 = 0.4 presented an obvious jump, characteristic of mesoporous materials. According to the IUPAC classification, all the isotherms with a similar shape were ascribed to the type H3 hysteresis loops [29]. Compared with the WO3-modified samples with relatively regular mesopores, the pure Fe2O3 and 1R-F samples had a less quantity of N2 adsorption with the hysteresis loop shifting approach P/P0 = 1.0 owing to the increased mesopore size [30]. As presented in Fig. 3(b), the pore size distribution curves demonstrated that the mesopore size of pure Fe2O3 and 1R-F samples was mainly focused on 43 and 43.2 nm, respectively. Besides, the mesopore size of 5 W-F and 1R-5W-F samples (15.2 and 19.6 nm, respectively) was more regular than that of WO3-free samples combined with the result of the average pore diameter presented in Table 1. According to the Table 1, it was found that the surface area of mesoporous Fe2O3 was 14.3 m2/g, which was similar to that of 1R-F (14.2 m2/g) catalyst. It was interesting that the surface area and pore volume of 5 W-F (36.6 m2/g and 0.19 cm3/g) and 1R-5W-F (32.8 m2/g and 0.20 cm3/g) increased remarkably comparing to those of free from tungsten oxide catalysts, concluding that the doping and deposition of tungsten oxide was inclined to form smaller pores, which contributed to the larger specific surface area of catalysts [31]. While the surface area of 1R-5W-F was smaller than that of 5 W-F catalyst, which might be assigned to the blockage on pores due to the Ru species. However, the catalytic activities of Fe2O3 and 1R-F were better than that of 5 W-F. Therefore, the surface area did not play an important role in catalytic reaction. 3.2.2 Raman spectroscopy To further study the structure of the catalysts, Raman spectra of two typical samples were conducted to examine their surface characteristics. As shown in Fig. 4 , the spectrum of 1R-F gave eight typical Raman bands of hematite (α-Fe2O3) with peaks at 224, 242, 289, 409, 500, 609, 658, and 815 cm−1 [32,33]. No other iron oxide species, such as maghemite or magnetite, were detected, which demonstrated that the product mainly existed in pure α-Fe2O3 phase. For 1R-5W-F sample, the Raman peaks of α-Fe2O3 phase presented a red shift (3–9 cm−1) to lower wavenumber, which indicated the existence of the strong interaction between Fe2O3 and WO3 species. Furthermore, decrease of intensity of Raman peaks of α-Fe2O3 phase due to the doping of WO3 clearly implied the decline of crystallinity of α-Fe2O3, which further verified the XRD results. 3.2.3 XPS surface chemical analysis XPS technique was employed to elucidate the chemical states of all the metal species, as well as the surface composition. The results of XPS spectra were summarized in Fig. 5 and Table 2 . As shown in Fig. 5(a), two main spectral signals with binding energies of 710.9 and 724.8 eV belonged to Fe 2p3/2 and Fe 2p1/2 peaks, respectively, that means the presence of Fe3+ ions in hematite (α-Fe2O3) phase as previously reported [34]. Obviously, no definite difference could be observed from XPS spectra of Fe 2p for the four samples. In terms of the W 4f spectra of WO3-doped samples (Fig. 5(b)), the W 4f7/2 binding energy of 35.6 eV and the corresponding W 4f5/2 peak at 37.8 eV could be solely assigned to the chemical state of W6+, which was well in agreement with the previous report of WO3 [35]. Furthermore, the Ru 3d spectra of 1R-F and 1R-5W-F catalysts were plotted in Fig. 5(c). As for the 1R-F sample, four peaks in the Ru 3d spectrum could be assigned to different Ru components in specific chemical environments; the peaks with binding energy of 281.4 and 285.6 eV were ascribed to 3d5/2 and 3d3/2 of Ru4+ in RuO2, whereas the other two peaks located at about 282.8 and 286.6 eV were consistent with that of Ru3+ from the hydrous Ru(Ⅲ)-OH species [36,37]. Furthermore, the main peak located at 284.7 eV was attributed to C1 s (sp2 CC). Note that the spectrum of C1 s region overlapped with that of Ru 3d spectrum [36]. Interestingly, a clear difference was observed between 1R-F and 1R-5W-F catalysts. It could be seen that the reduction of the content of ruthenium oxide species on the surface of WO3-modified sample occurred. The O1 s spectra as displayed in Fig. 5(d) could be resolved to two peaks. The peaks located at lower binding energy of 529.0–531.0 eV were ascribed to the surface lattice oxygen (labeled as Oα), and the peaks centered at higher binding energy of 531.0–533.0 eV belonged to the surface chemisorbed oxygen (denoted as Oβ) [38]. It had been shown that Oβ was more active than Oα for oxidation reactions due to its higher mobility, while Oα was more selective in partially oxidizing ammonia into N2 [39]. The relative concentration ratios of Oα/(Oα+Oβ) for WO3-modified samples collected in Table 2 were higher than those for pure Fe2O3 and 1R-F, which was well consistent with the results of N2 selectivity shown in Fig. 1. 3.2.4 H2-TPR analysis To obtain the redox ability of the prepared catalysts, TPR experiment was conducted. As we all know that the measurement conditions played an important role in H2-TPR results and a set of suitable test conditions were applied [40]. Fig. 6 gave the TPR patterns of all the catalysts. The pristine Fe2O3 showed a sharp peak at 380 °C ascribed to the transformation of Fe2O3 into Fe3O4 and the another broad reduction peak at temperatures upper than 600 °C with great H2 consumption amount was related to the further reduction of Fe3O4 to FeO and Fe [41]. Compared to that of the pure Fe2O3, the reduction peak of Fe2O3 to Fe3O4 in the 1R-F sample shifted to lower temperature, indicating that RuO2 exerted a positive effect on the ease of Fe2O3 reduction. It also revealed that the considerable enhancement ability of RuO2 in the reduction of Fe2O3 might be due to the spillover of hydrogen from ruthenium atoms to iron oxide [42]. Besides, a new weak reduction peak appeared at about 142 °C, which might be ascribed to the reduction of RuO x species [43]. It was important to note that the reduction behavior of 5 W-F and 1R-5W-F catalysts changed obviously after introducing the WO3 species. The first reduction peak of Fe2O3 to Fe3O4 shifted to higher temperature (474 and 453 °C) and the latter overlapped reduction peak appeared above 600 °C could be due to the co-reduction of WO3 and FeO x species [44]. This fact indicated that the strong interaction between Fe2O3 and WO3 over WO3-doped samples decreased the redox property of them, leading to a lower activity of 5 W-F compared to the pure Fe2O3. However, the 1R-5W-F catalyst showed a great catalytic performance, which might be due to the synergistic effect between RuO2 and Fe2O3. Peng et al. [45] also discovered that MoO3 doped on CeO2 resulting in the lower reducibility, although the activity of NH3-SCR of NO x was improved. It was noted that the reducibility of catalysts was not a determining factor in catalytic performance. Additionally, the corresponding total H2 consumptions of catalysts were summarized in Table 1. It was noticeable that the total H2 consumption of catalysts was closely related with the introduction of WO3. It could be seen that the amount of consumed H2 significantly decreased when WO3 mixed with Fe2O3 and 1R-F catalysts, which further indicated that the introduction of WO3 limited the reduction of FeO x species. 3.3 In situ DRIFT spectra analysis of catalysts 3.3.1 In situ DRIFT spectra of surface acidities It was well known that the surface acidity of catalyst played a key role in NH3-SCO reaction and the in situ DRIFT spectra of NH3 adsorption could give the information of catalyst surface acidity. Firstly, the DRIFTS studies of NH3 adsorption on the 5 W-F, 1R-F and 1R-5W-F catalysts at different temperatures were employed and the results were illustrated in Fig. 7 . Prior to the experiment of NH3 adsorption, the catalysts were firstly treated with N2 for 20 min at 400 °C to remove the undesired species, and then collected the background spectra in flowing nitrogen atmosphere. When cooling to the target temperature of 50 °C, 600 ppm NH3 was pumped into the reaction chamber for 20 min, subsequently the in situ DRIFT spectra were collected with the increasing temperature from 50 °C to 350 °C. For 5 W-F sample (Fig. 7(a)), several bands at 3339, 3249, 3144, 1678, 1608–1628, 1407-1430, 1260 and 1143-1209 cm−1 were found after the catalyst was pretreated by 600 ppm NH3 at different temperatures. The bands at 3339, 3249, 3144 cm−1 were ascribed to the N-H stretching vibration modes of coordinated NH3 [46,47]. The features at 1608–1628, 1260 and 1143-1209 cm−1 were assigned to the coordinated NH3 linked to Lewis acid sites, while those at 1678 and 1407–1430 cm−1 were attributed to symmetric and asymmetric modes of NH4 + species chemisorbed on Brønsted acid sites [48–50]. It was worth noting that the NH3 adsorbed on Brønsted acid sites was less intense with increasing the temperature, while the intensities of those bands ascribed to Lewis acid sites decreased slightly, indicating that the adsorbed NH3 on Lewis acid sites was more thermally stable than those on Brønsted acid sites. As for the 1R-5W-F sample (Fig. 7(b)), obvious bands centered at 3350, 3248, 3151, 1666, 1585, 1413–1433 and 1206-1219 cm−1 appeared after NH3 adsorption. The intensities of bands ascribed to Brønsted acid sites (1666, 1413–1433 cm−1) decreased sharply with increasing the temperature and disappeared at 350 °C. Whereas NH3 species was more stable on Lewis acid sites (1206–1219 cm−1), which remained at 400 °C [51]. Moreover, a new weak band at 1585 cm−1 assigned to the amide (−NH2) scissoring appeared at 150 °C [20]. These results indicated that upon heating, some adsorbed NH3 on 1R-5W-F formed − NH2 through abstraction of hydrogen likely (reactions (10), (11) in the presence of ruthenium oxide species. (10) NH3 → NH2 + H (11) NH2 → NH + H (12) NH + O → HNO However, 1R-F sample (Fig. 7(c)) showed the absolutely different DRIFT spectra compared to WO3-doped samples. It was quite clear here that in the case of 1R-F catalyst the bands attributed to Lewis acid sites (1143–1214, 1613 cm−1) were less intense than that of 5 W-F and 1R-5W-F catalysts. And that in the absence of WO3 sample these signals attributed to the Brønsted acid sites (1392, 1666 cm−1) and –NH (1453 cm−1) did not appeared until the temperature increased to 250 °C [20,50,52,53]. Besides, some bands at 1313, 1511, 1806 and 1895 cm−1 appeared at a lower temperature of 150–250 °C. The bands at 1313 and 1511 cm−1 could be ascribed to the bidentate nitrate [54,55]; and the bands at 1806 and 1895 cm−1 could be ascribed to the nitrosyl (−HNO) species [56,57]. These results demonstrated that the adsorbed NH3 could be activated and reacted with surface oxygen on surface active sites even though at a low temperature of 150 °C (reactions (10)–(12)). In summary, it was evident that the WO3-doped catalysts possessed more surface acid sites than that of the WO3-free catalyst. Moreover, NH3 species were adsorbed tightly on surface acid sites of 5 W-F and 1R-5W-F catalysts in the form of stable intermediates, which contributed to the formation of N2. For 1R-F catalyst, however, the adsorbed NH3 species were activated and reacted with active oxygen species rapidly to form NO x , which adsorbed on the surface of 1R-F catalyst in the form of nitrate species. 3.3.2 In situ DRIFT spectra of the activation of reactants The reaction behaviors on the surface of 5 W-F, 1R-F and 1R-5W-F catalysts were investigated by performing an in situ DRIFTS study and the results were shown in Fig. 8 . The samples were first pretreated with 600 ppm NH3 for 20 min at 250 °C (or 350 °C) and then purged with N2 flow. 5% O2 was subsequently introduced into the IR cell and the spectra were collected as a function of time (Fig. 8). As noted above, the adsorbed NH3 species bonded to Brønsted acid sites (1672, 1424 cm−1) and Lewis acid sites (1186, 1605 cm−1) of 5 W-F catalyst at 250 °C (Fig. 8(a)-1) were observed on the surface of the 5 W-F sample in the presence of NH3 [48, 49]. When O2 was introduced, all of these bands became weaker, and then remained stable with further increasing the O2 purging time. No other bands, however, were found during this progress, indicating that desorption of ammonia on catalyst surface occurred and the reaction behavior could not determine yet. As the adsorption temperature increased to 350 °C, the bands assigned to Lewis acid sites (1608, 1209 cm−1) and Brønsted acid sites (1407) appeared (Fig. 8(a)-2). Interestingly, a new weak band assigned to bidentate nitrate (1519 cm−1) was found and became clearer after introducing a flow of O2 [54]. Simultaneously, the bands at 1608 and 1209 cm−1 became more and more weak, and the latter band was also shifted to 1241 cm−1 with the prolonged time exposure to O2. Therefore, the addition of gas-phase O2 led to the occurrence of surface reaction at a higher temperature of 350 °C. Fig. 8(b) showed the DRIFT spectra of 1R-5W-F catalyst during continuous flow of O2 for 20 min at 250 and 350 °C, respectively, after NH3 pretreatment. NH3 species coordinated to Lewis acid sites (1610 cm−1) got a disappearance after introduction of O2 flow at 250 °C (Fig. 8(b)-1), while those adsorbed on Brønsted acid sites remained stable. The another band assigned to adsorbed NH3 bound to Lewis acid sites shifted from 1201 to 1219 cm−1, and the intensity of it decreased sharply with the increase of introduced time of O2, indicating their consumption by reacting with gaseous O2. Therefore, the new species assigned to monodentate nitrate (1533 cm−1) was observed in the spectra [51,58]. When the temperature increased to 350 °C, the pre-adsorbed NH3 species on 1R-5W-F were disappeared absolutely after exposing to O2 for 1 min (Fig. 8(b)-2). Meanwhile, three new bands were found at 1513, 1313 and 1146 cm−1. The features at 1513 and 1313 cm−1 were ascribed to the bidentate nitrate species, while the band centered at 1146 cm−1 was assigned to the nitrate species [59,60]. According to the above results of DRIFTS and previous researches [20], we were apt to accept that the reaction of ammonia oxidation happened on WO3-contained samples followed the “internal” selective catalytic reduction (iSCR) mechanism, and the reaction pathway could take place as follows: (13) O2 → 2 O (14) HNO + O → NO + OH (15) NH2 + NO → N2 + H2O (16) NH + NO → N2O + H (17) H + OH → H2O (18) NH3 + 3O2 → 2N2 + 6H2O The adsorbed NH3 species was firstly transformed into the amide (-NH2), imide (-NH) and nitrosyl (-HNO) species through the reaction of dehydrogenation and oxidation (reactions (10)–(12)). Then, the nitrosyl (-HNO) species was oxidized to the NO by atomic oxygen. NO was subsequently reduced by -NH2 to generate the main product of nitrogen and water (reactions (13)–(15)). The by-reaction (16) happened at the same time and formed a small amount of N2O. Noticeably, it was found that only a few nitrate species generated on the WO3-contained samples even though at a higher temperature of 350 °C. The reaction (18) was the overall reaction of NH3-SCO. While for 1R-F catalyst, the bands ascribed to the Lewis acid sites (1186 cm−1) and nitrosyl (1895, 1806 cm−1) diminished with introducing a flow of O2 (Fig. 8(c)-1). Meanwhile, some new bands at 1849, 1550 and 1329 cm−1 appeared and the intensities of them increased slightly with the increase of introducing time of O2. The bands at 1849 and 1550 cm−1 were attributed to the nitrate species, and the band at 1329 cm−1 was assigned to amide (-NH2) species [61,62]. Furthermore, the band intensity of imide (–NH) at 1453 cm−1 also increased sharply after O2 introduced [19]. Similarly, when the reaction temperature increased to 350 °C, the pre-adsorbed NH3 species disappeared rapidly after introducing the O2 flow (Fig. 8(c)-2). Simultaneously, some new bands ascribed to nitrate species (1868, 1543 cm−1) and amide (-NH2) species (1330 cm−1), respectively, were present on 1R-F catalyst [20,62–64]. Generally, NH3 species were oxidized quickly even though at the conditions of lower temperature and O2-free, indicating the surface of 1R-F catalyst possessed many activity sites. Additionally, more nitrate species generated at a higher temperature above 250 °C than that of WO3-contained catalysts, suggesting the NH3-SCO over 1R-F followed the iSCR mechanism, too. These phenomena demonstrated that ammonia species were also oxidized by gaseous O2 to form NO at temperatures above 250 °C (reaction (19)), and the formed adsorbed NO was further oxidized to nitrate species on 1R-F catalyst. According to the Fig. 1(c), the NO x yield of WO3-free sample was much higher than that of WO3-contained samples during the ammonia oxidation in the presence of gas-phase O2. As a result, the observed nitrate species must be a result of NO x formation via ammonia oxidation with the participation of surface atomic oxygen and gaseous O2. Moreover, the modification of WO3 played a significant role in the suppression of further oxidation of these surface species by the available oxygen species, which contributed to the high N2 selectivity over a wide temperature range (150–400 °C). (19) NH + O2 → NO + OH 3.4 Stability of the catalyst The long-term stability test is significant in the evaluation of a catalyst. For the best 1R-5W-F catalyst, thus, an additional long-term catalytic stability test was performed at 250 °C for 30 h. As illustrated in Fig. 9 , the NH3 conversion and N2 selectivity of 1R-5W-F catalyst could remain stable during the entire period of time of the test. In general, 100% NH3 conversion and >92% N2 selectivity was achieved at 250 °C during 30 h. Therefore, it was clearly suggested that 1R-5W-F catalyst displayed the excellent durability, which was a promising candidate for NH3-SCO reaction. 4 Conclusions In summary, a series of novel WO3 promoted 1RuO2-Fe2O3 catalysts had been developed for selective catalytic oxidation of ammonia to nitrogen in the presence of oxygen. Although the 1RuO2-Fe2O3 catalyst showed an excellent low-temperature catalytic activity for ammonia oxidation, the addition of WO3 gave a surprising effect on promotion of N2 selectivity at high temperature (>300 °C). Besides, the characterization results revealed that the decline of Fe2O3 crystallinity and reducibility was happened on the 1RuO2-5WO3-Fe2O3 sample due to the strong interaction between WO3 and Fe2O3. Most importantly, in situ DRIFTS results demonstrated that the iSCR mechanism was predominant on ammonia oxidation over 1RuO2-5WO3-Fe2O3 catalyst. The key intermediate (-NH2) could promptly react with the in situ-generated NO x ad-species to form N2. Meanwhile, the introduction of WO3 to 1RuO2-Fe2O3 was a powerful approach to tune the surface acidity, as well as control the reaction of adsorbed NO with reactive oxygen to generate NO2 and surface nitrate species in NH3-SCO. As a result, high N2 selectivity over 1RuO2-5WO3-Fe2O3 catalyst was facilitated. coredata.dc:description: The promoting effects of WO3 on RuO2-Fe2O3 catalyst were systematically investigated for the selective catalytic oxidation of ammonia to nitrogen. It was found that the introduction of 5 wt.% WO3 led to a dramatic promoting effect on the high-temperature N2 selectivity of RuO2-Fe2O3 catalyst, giving 100% NH3 conversion at 250 °C and 94% N2 selectivity at a high temperature of 400 °C. In depth analysis using XRD, Raman and H2-TPR revealed that the addition of WO3 into the RuO2-Fe2O3 catalyst could strongly inhibit the crystallinity of Fe2O3 and decrease the reducibility of RuO2-Fe2O3 catalyst, which were related to the strong interaction between WO3 and Fe2O3. Moreover, in situ DRIFTS studies illustrated that the ammonia oxidation over 1RuO2-5WO3-Fe2O3 catalyst followed the iSCR mechanism, involving the oxidation of NH3 into NO species and the reaction of -NH2 with in situ-formed NO to form N2. The introduction of WO3 not only promoted the formation of more acid sites on the catalyst surface but also restrained the formation of nitrate species at high temperature, with few NO x formed, which contributed to the high N2 selectivity.
coredata.dc:title: Promotional mechanism of WO3 over RuO2-Fe2O3 catalyst for NH3-SCO reaction
